Gordon Brown went to the Queen to request the dissolution of parliament on Tuesday, so we're in to the campaign for the general election, which will be held on 6th May. For those who don't know, this is election for the house of commons, 650 Members of Parliament, each elected by a constituency with a population around the 100k mark requiring a plurality of votes in their constituency.
 
 It looks like being a close election, with key marginal seats having both major parties, Labour and Conservative, neck and neck. It looks likely that the Conservatives will be the largest party, but will not have a majority in the commons, and may be outnumbered by an alliance between Labour and the Liberal Democrats. A hung parliament, as this situation is known, hasn't happened in my lifetime, but will likely result in a radical overhaul of the voting system, possibly replacing the current system with the Alternative Vote, or with the top-up system used in Scotland and Wales, to ensure fairer representation.
 
 Away from the main result, there is a risk of the Neo-Nazi BNP taking a seat, and the hope (rather more likely, thankfully) that the Green Party will take their first seat, in Brighton. Other interesting things to watch will be performance of pro-independence parties in Scotland and Wales, particularly with polling indicating a small majority in favour of independence in Scotland if a Conservative government is elected in Westminster.
 
 The main story of this election is whether loathing of the Conservatives or anger with Labour is the more powerful emotion, or weather voters will declare a plague on both your houses and either abstain or vote for smaller parties less tarnished by the expenses scandal and years of warmongering.
 
 Discuss!

I took a test at 
 
 Welcome to the Vote for Policies Survey - Vote for Policies - Vote for policies, not personalities!
 
 and got my results as 33% lib Dem, 33% Green Party, 22% Labour and 11% UKIP.
 
 I am doing further reading on the Lib Dems and they will probably be getting my vote even though I disagree with their Trident policy. I can not see myself voting for any of the other parties. Still, my vote is perhaps more important than most as my constituency is closely fought over between the Tories and Lib Dems.
Yeah, did that one too, got 100% Green, as if anyone was surprised.

The campaign is getting very interesting. The liberal democrats, the third party in British politics (in one guise or another) for almost a century, have drawn level with the other main parties, and there are only a few points between all of them. They won't win, or even be the largest party, because of imbalances in the electoral system, but it is looking inevitable that there will be a hung parliament, and we will get electoral reform.

I have really enjoyed the T.V debates, it certainly got people talking. Unfortunately, due to the increasing popularity of the Lib Dems, I can no longer vote for them. When it only determined my local MP they were palatable but I won't endorse them to run the country.
 
 My choice now comes down to whether I can be arsed to spoil my ballot paper or not.

I have really enjoyed the T.V debates, it certainly got people talking. Unfortunately, due to the increasing popularity of the Lib Dems, I can no longer vote for them. When it only determined my local MP they were palatable but I won't endorse them to run the country.
 
 My choice now comes down to whether I can be arsed to spoil my ballot paper or not.

 
 There's no risk of them getting a majority, don't worry. The system is rigged too heavily against them. They just need enough votes to force electoral reform through. If they come out as the largest party by vote share but third in the number of seats (as looks more than possible), then there will be real impetus to change the voting system.

 I understand Nick Clegg is the fresh face , the new darling so as to speak but what does he stand for other than being "not Labor or Tory".

Actually we have gone more left since the start of Bush. 
 
 emoticon_rolleyes Are you going to blame big business for everything?

 
 
 But there are some curious peculiar things which don't fit the definition of left and right .
 
 Bush was right but had "liberal" views on illegal immigration. Reagan gave amnesty to MILLIONS of illegal immigrants. Any "left" politician in Europe who did that would lose elections in Europe in a wink of an eye. They even have problems with Eastern European EU immigrants, imagine giving amnesty to millions of illegal immigrants in Europe!!
 
 Most European parties on the left are against illegal immigrants and indeed there are no illegal immigrants marching and demanding rights as it happens in the USA because it would not be tolerated by the so called supposedly enlightened "humane" Europeans.
 
 
 
 
 In Britain all three contenders in the election are are male whites, no minorites . But they are considered left of the Democrats..hummm
 
 When it comes to race, the "right" in America is more "left" than the left in Europe. When did Europe ever have a minority foreign minister (equivalent of secretary of state). Bush had two , "enlightened humane left" Europe = Zero 
 
 Some unpleasant facts to be considered. Europe would never tolerate 10/12 million illegal immigrants. They even have trouble integrating legal immigrants.

Clegg is in favour of joining the Euro in principle, when the economic conditions are right, and only after a referendum vote in favour. The conditions are clearly not right at the moment.
 
 As to all the party leaders being white, there are several reasons for that. First is that ethnic minorities make up barely 10% of the population, compared with 25-35% in the US. Second is that the UK has had a significant ethnic minority population for maybe 50 years, whereas there have been black and hispanic Americans for as long as the US has existed. There is also a seperate culture of black and hispanic politics in the US that isn't mirrored in the UK, and party leaders are selected internally, not in open primaries. There is also the issue that class is still a major factor in British politics, and it takes time to work your way up through party structures. There isn't the same ability to ride into power on a wave of popular support as Obama did.
 
 The big thing Clegg stands for as far as I'm concerned (and I'm not voting lib dem, I'm voting Green) is electoral reform. Nobody expects him to form a majority government, but there is some hope he'll reform the electoral system to avoid the tyranny of tactical voting that has kept Labour and the Tories in power for almost a century.

 The criteria for this is that they had to be here for over 10 years, I don't know how they would prove this given the lack of documentation illegal immigrants carry. In the last debate the Tories said that it could mean as many as 600,000 people being given amnesty which the Lib Dems didn't deny. Each of these people would then be allowed to invite one more and so the number doubles to 1.2 million. This is an awful lot for the welfare system to have to accommodate.
 
 The other parties said that this would make Britain look like a soft touch though the Lib Dems do want to increase border control and and put in polices to make sure that future immigration is manageable. I believe all this only refers to immigrants from outside the EU. 
 
 Overall I am undecided on this. This may be a pragmatic approach in trying to remove the backlog from a failed system i.e. the difficulties in removing these people due to the Human Rights Act or simply being able to prove where exactly they came from but the offer for them to invite 1 person each seems overly generous. If they have been here 10 years then I feel they would have severed any ties they had outside the country.

 As to all the party leaders being white, there are several reasons for that. First is that ethnic minorities make up barely 10% of the population, compared with 25-35% in the US. 
 

 
 1) Blacks make up about barely 11-12% of the US population and yet the USA has a black president.
 
 2) Ethnic minorities are 25% of the US population and Hispanics about 13-14% Which brings out a difference between USA and Europe regarding Hispanics. In Europe, spanish people are not considered minorities and a lot of Hispanics in USA would not be considered as minorities in Europe - example (Hispanic supreme court Justice Sotoyamer). So by European standards, the minorities in USA would be about 15 % not much higher than Britain's.
 
 
 

 Second is that the UK has had a significant ethnic minority population for maybe 50 years, .
 

 
 Same as Canada but Canada's head of state (Governor General) is a black who came to this country as an Haitian immigrant.
 
 Which is why Britain's lack of minorities in high government positions is striking even when compared to other countries with similar history with minority populations. 
 
 
 
 
 
 

 The big thing Clegg stands for as far as I'm concerned (and I'm not voting lib dem, I'm voting Green) is electoral reform. Nobody expects him to form a majority government, but there is some hope he'll reform the electoral system to avoid the tyranny of tactical voting that has kept Labour and the Tories in power for almost a century.

 Spending billions on the upkeep of an EU bureaucracy with mega salaries and spending billions to bail out certain EURO countries instead of speading those billions in science & research, technoligy, education to compete in the new gobal world. Surely China & India must be laughing.

Basically immigrants should be let in as our needs dictatte , not on the worth of the immigrant. These resourceful people can get busy working towards the long term development of their original countries.

It appears the shine has come off a bit for Nick Clegg when his expense claims of 84,000 pounds at taxpapers expense for his second home was recently exposed.
 
 A bit hypocritical since he has made a big deal about cleaning up politics.
 
 
 Full article : MPs' expenses: Nick Clegg defends £84,000 expenses on 'modest' second home - Telegraph
 
 
 The Liberal Democrat leader was challenged after he billed the taxpayer for a new kitchen at the constituency house, redecoration, gardening and soft furnishings.
 
 
 NICK CLEGG DEFENDS £84,000 EXPENSES ON 'MODEST' SECOND HOME
 
 
 In total he claimed £83,824 between 2005 and 2009, including £1,018 in monthly mortgage interest payments; £9,244 in legal costs and stamp duty; £2,600 on a new kitchen; and £5,857 on decorating. 
 
 Mr Clegg also bought Ikea cushions, napkins and a cake pan, and also spent £850 on curtains and blinds. 
 
 He regularly paid a gardener £160 a month, with his tasks including “pruning of apple and plum trees”, and maintenance of the rose garden.

 Looks like the Murdoch press is pulling out all the stops. I liked the woeful mispresentation of current polling - most polls have lib dems and labour level on 28, tories on 35. The idea that lib dem support has collapsed is a fiction, and it's probably higher than that because youth turnout will likely be higher than previously, due to changes to registration, and the polls are skewed to traditional voting patterns.

 Is this a good source for polling? UK Polling Report
 
 But, my main point is that I agree with what the article was saying...it doesn't seem to me any of the candidates that can fulfill these goals.

 
 I don't think the goals are necessarily valid, and certainly not the subtext of how to achieve them. Last time the tories took power in a bad economy, there were 3.5 million unemployed and a further 7 million hidden in the sickness benefit figures within a few years. Only the Falklands war kept them in power on a tide of jingoism. Within another 7 years they crashed the economy again.
 
 @ gansao: people don't want the Daily Mail propagated myth of what multi-culturalism is. Most people are quite happy for people of all faiths and backgrounds to live their lives as they see fit within the law. I've heard this "thousands of unneeded jobs" meme before, do you have a list? I suspect a lot of them are, ironically, linked to trying to avoid wasting money - at the behest of the right wing media. It's not dissimilar to the amount spent in the US on claims adjusters.

New labour inherited a very robust economy in 1997 .
 They have followed the old labour tax and spend mentality, creating thousands of unneeded jobs in the the public sector .
 They rode on the back of booming house price bubble and now the bubble has burst.
 They forced multicultural Britain on a Britain who did not want multiculturalism and made the BNP what they are today, they gave Scotland its own parliament and made Alex Salmond what he is today..............

Finally, 3 party politics, we've waited ruddy long enough.
 The electoral system does need reform, if you're in a safe seat there's no point getting out of bed.
 We do need to sort out the economy and the sooner we start the better.
 Immigration - Something of a moot point in Wales, if you don't speak Welsh you can't get a job, end of story. 
 Welsh independence is a non-starter, we have 80% public sector employment, 10% unemployment and most of those who have a real job are on minimum wage. Independence would see the welsh civil servants joining the Dole Queue faster than you can blink.
 Labour has absolutely no connection with people outside the cities and are completely incompetent with rural issues, from Foot & Mouth to the most recent **** up on Game Bird regulation.
 On Health Labour tries to claim credit for creating the NHS then remove services. Just before the Election we were presented with plans to make Mental Health services no longer free at point of use and that isn't the only thing we might wind up paying for...
 Lib-Dems seem to have the best policy so far as Mental Health is concerned, whether or not Clegg can push that through with Cameron remains to be seen.

I don't think the goals are necessarily valid, and certainly not the subtext of how to achieve them. So Nick Clegg is deputy Prime minister.
 
 What does that mean? Is it sort of like vice-president and if God forbid Cameron is suddenly "gone", Nick step into his shoes?

So Nick Clegg is deputy Prime minister.
 
 What does that mean? Is it sort of like vice-president and if God forbid Cameron is suddenly "gone", Nick step into his shoes?

 
 Not really. It's mostly an empty title. When Cameron goes on holiday, Clegg might step in (though there is no constitutional requirement for that). If Cameron keels over, there will be a leadership contest in the Conservative party and there would be a new PM, though if they can't hold the coalition together there would have to be a general election. Clegg might be acting PM in the interim but would not take over in the same way a US VP would.

Thanks Jo Bennett, that explains it very well.
 
 I wonder though why he didn't take a cabinet seat instead of this powerless position.

Thanks Jo Bennett, that explains it very well.
 
 I wonder though why he didn't take a cabinet seat instead of this powerless position.

 
 It is a cabinet seat, it's just not a departmental position. He's taken it because he wants to effectively be the co prime minister, having a finger in every pie and not restricted to one area of policy. Not a bad position if Cameron is serious about truly having cabinet government. It's worth remembering that most positions in the British government are what you and those around you make of them, they're not legislatively or constitutionally defined.

It is a cabinet seat, it's just not a departmental position. He's taken it because he wants to effectively be the co prime minister, having a finger in every pie and not restricted to one area of policy. Not a bad position if Cameron is serious about truly having cabinet government. It's worth remembering that most positions in the British government are what you and those around you make of them, they're not legislatively or constitutionally defined.

I agree the EU would go bananas if Britain went to war over the Falklands.
 
 I suspect the Argies know this and probably have got private assurances from the big boys in the EU (French & Germans) that the EU would put pressure on Britain, in return for Argentina buying French planes etc.

 The sudden boldness of the Argies in demanding the return of the Falkands makes me suspicious that they would not do it unless they had some support from important players.

 
 Fom the following wiki link
 
 Falkland Islands sovereignty dispute - Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
 
 Supporters of the British claim
 
 
The European Union classes the islands as a special overseas territory, subject to EU law in some areas, and eligible for some European funding initiatives. The inclusion of the islands in an appendix to the proposed European Constitution provoked a hostile Argentine response. Its mention is retained in the treaty replacing the abandoned Constitution, the Treaty of Lisbon.
 
 France has been particularly supportive of the British position, and provided invaluable help to the British military on the French supplied aircraft and missiles of the Argentine military during the Falklands War. France is also motivated by the fact that it, like the UK, retains many overseas territories that are subject to rival sovereignty claims including the Glorioso Islands, Mayotte and Tromelin.

 
 But if you have some information about the French backing the Argentinians I would like to see it.
 
 Still like Gansao said, the Argentinians are limited in their options.

I just used the Falklands as an example, there could be any number of issues that could cause disagreement and, as I said, it's not the disagreement itself but how it is resolved that will decide the fate of this government.

But if you have some information about the French backing the Argentinians I would like to see it.
 
 
 

 
 I don't have any information on French backing the Argentinians as the French are not going to expose any shady "you scratch my back, I scratch your back" deal to the outside world.
 
 But I do know that in these days of economic hard times, the French number one priority is French jobs . Case in point, soon after the French backed Brazil's bid to hold the olympics in Brazil, the Brazilian government put in a big order for French military hardware. In Brazil it is common knowledge that a French vote for Brazil was exhanged for purchases of French military goods. The timing was just too suspicious.
 
 All, I am saying is the Argentinians are not above holding the possiblities of lucratives business deals to important EU players to put pressure on Britain. And the French and/or Germans are not above declining these lucrative deals in exchange for pressure on Britain over Falklands. And lets be frank, French jobs will always triump EU solidarity with Britain.
 
 Sure the French have overseas terrorities but they have never fought a war over them in recent memory like the Falkands nor do they face a strong persistent emotional claim to any of their overseas islands similar to Argentina's feelings towards the Falklands. 
 
 The bottom line is no country would be willing to go to war to claim back French overseas islands and the French know this.

I just used the Falklands as an example, there could be any number of issues that could cause disagreement and, as I said, it's not the disagreement itself but how it is resolved that will decide the fate of this government.

I suspect the message got mangled somewhere...emoticon_confused
 Brussels is an entirely seperate issue from the Falklands and one that splits parties, never mind coalitions.
 
 Going back to the Falklands debate, it has absolutely nothing to do with proximity on either side.
 The Argentinian claim stems from the fact that the islands were once Spanish territory and Argentina is the local former Spanish colony. Thus a more accurate analogy for Americans would be Mexico claiming sovereignty over Texas.
 
 As for French help for the Argentinians during '82. Who do you think sent the activation codes for the Exocet missiles which Argentina did not have prior to the invasion?

As for French help for the Argentinians during '82. Who do you think sent the activation codes for the Exocet missiles which Argentina did not have prior to the invasion?

 
 Would you please elaborate?
 
 Is this article accurate?
 
 How France helped us win Falklands war, by John Nott - Telegraph
 
 Edit: From wiki
 
 http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Events_leading_to_the_Falklands_War#French_involvement
 
 French involvement
 
 President of France François Mitterrand gave full support to the UK in the Falklands war. Sir John Nott, who was Secretary of State for Defence during the conflict, has acknowledged in his memoirs that "in so many ways Mitterrand and the French were our greatest allies".[25] A large part of Argentina's military equipment was French-made, so French support was crucial. Sir John has revealed that France provided Mirage and Etendard aircraft, identical to the ones that it supplied to Argentina, for British pilots to train against. It is also disclosed in Sir John's memoirs that France provided intelligence to help fight the Exocet missiles that it had sold to Argentina, including details of special electronic countermeasures that at the time were only known to the French armed forces. In her memoirs, Margaret Thatcher says of Mitterrand that "I never forgot the debt we owed him for his personal support...throughout the Falklands Crisis". As France had recently sold Super Etendard aircraft and Exocet missiles to the Argentine Navy, there was still a French team in Argentina helping to fit out the Exocets and aircraft for Argentine use at the beginning of the war. Argentina claims that the team left for France soon after the April 2 invasion, but according to Dr. James Corum, the French team apparently continued to assist the Argentines throughout the war in spite of the NATO embargo and official French government policy.[26]

Going back a bit now but the missiles were new, still in the cases when the invasion happened. Britain recieved reassurances from France that no more missiles would be delivered to Argentina untill the crisis had passed. Though this didn't include stopping deliveries to third parties who sprang up in neighbouring countries. This led to a bidding war with MI6 buying up as many stray missiles from the open market at deliberately over inflated prices, as it could find.
 However the Argentines still couldn't launch the missiles without the activation codes which France hadn't provided at the time of the invasion.
 The French government again reassured Britain that the codes would not be provided to Argentina, however the Argentines were able to gain the codes, apparently via an official in the French Civil Service, whist the RN Task Force was still en route.
 I should note that Argentines recieved the launch codes, but not the arming codes which was why the missiles failed to detonate on impact.
 Ships were lost becuase they ruptured fuel lines as they passed through the hull.
 
 The article is acurate as far as it goes, though obviously Sir John is being rather diplomatic in certain aspects.
 There are several books dealing with the events though it will be some years before MI6 discloses the whole operation (2022).

Anyone who studies the tortuous Xhistory and law of the Falklands will know that Argentina's claim to the islands was certainly strong. The treaty of Utrecht recognised Spanish sovereignty and this led to 40 years of Spanish occupation of the islands, which was reasserted in 1823 by Buenos Aires after its independence from Spain. Ten years later the islands were seized by force by Britain, and settlers sent out in a crude act of imperial aggression.
 
 Argentina protested its right to the islands then and since, regularly Xregistering it with the UN's decolonisation committee, supported by other post-imperial states in south and north America. Thirty-two Latin American countries reasserted that support in Mexico this week with even the US sympathetic, conspicuously refusing to side with Britain on what it too sees as a post-imperial issue.
 
 The Falklands can no longer remain as Britain's expensive nuisance | Simon Jenkins | Comment is free | The Guardian

I can just imagine what would have happened if an American oil company had caused a spill on the British coastline.
 
 The Guardian would have gone into an anti-American binge for months not to mention a good number of Brits would taken the opportunity to vent their anger and proclaim their moral superiority.
 
 There would have been millions of articles, speeches from British politicians & environmentalists visciously attacking American companies - how they don't care about the environment, how they only care about making money at the expense of the British coastline, how incompetent American companies are, how ineffiicient, money crazy etc etc.
 I can just see the headlines "what? it takes those stupid Americans months to stop a leak?"
 
 One accident would have been enough to moral pass judgement on the character of all American companies and by extension the values of American society. Anti-Americanism would have reigned supreme for months.
 
 But when a British oil company causes a spill - oh well, accidents happen....as we all know there is always a double standard when it concerns the Americans
 
 
 The US media had behaved with remarkable restraint considering the magnitude of environmental/economic damage this oil spill would do to the US coastline, the British media would not have behaved with equal restraint had the situation been reversed.
 
 .

To be fair, the Guardian have laid into BP anyway. e.g.
 Time for BP to stop blame game | Jules Boykoff | Comment is free | guardian.co.uk
 
 I think the difference is to do with the attack-dog style of much of the British press. They will any available stick with which to beat an enemy, often using contadictory sticks on different days. The US media is generally more deferential in style. Jon Snow suggested this was a result of the freedom of information culture in the US - the British media is used to having to fight for every morsel of information they can get out of the government in a way that the US media isn't.

What one newspaper the Guardian said about BP is nothing compared to the storm that would have erupted in Britain if an American oil company had an oil spill along the British coastline.
 
 And I am not just talking about the media, but environmentalists, politicians and a good number of ordinary Brits would have been bashing Americans in general as greedy, incompetent, stupid etc etc.
 
 There is always a double standard for Americans.

Sure, but if it had been Royal Dutch Shell causing a spill of the British coast then the press would still go after them. What I'm saying is that you're right about the likely outcome, but wrong about it being a double standard - the British press will use any tactic at their disposal once they've decided to attack.
